review: This is the second book I’ve read by Patricia Osborne. I loved her novel The Oath so much that I decided to read her previous work. All I can say is tThis is the second book I’ve read by Patricia Osborne. I loved her novel The Oath so much that I decided to read her previous work. All I can say is that House of Grace won’t be the last one I read. That’s a given. I look forward to the other two books in this series.Grace is a wonderful character. Born to great wealth, she doesn’t hesitate to give it all up when she falls madly in love with a coal miner. She pour herself into their life together. Her background and his don’t matter: love does. A strong woman, even in her young years, Grace endures what she must to follow her heart.That’s about all I want to say about the plot: no desire to ruin it for anyone. What draws me into this author’s work is Osborne's storytelling, her understanding of family (good, bad, and in-between), and the emotions that her characters and their respective situations stir in me. She isn't afraid to take us where her characters lead—whether that be in the sunshine or the dark shade. Her writing is relatable and strong—her stories compelling. For readers who love family drama, I highly recommend this author and this book....more

review: This is the second volume of poetry I’ve read by Wendy Slater. I knew when I read the first one, I would indeed return for more.Slater is an extraordiThis is the second volume of poetry I’ve read by Wendy Slater. I knew when I read the first one, I would indeed return for more.Slater is an extraordinarily talented poet. I love reading her words. They’re so rich in imagery and with each poem, I stop to visualize what interpretation my past experiences and my imagination have joined forces to present to me in concert with Slater’s artistry. I wonder what the story is behind her words, and how close it may be to my own. I read every poem multiple times to truly feel the weight of the words. I only wish I were able to  this poetry as well as Slater writes it. For me, that is beyond impossible. In 1608, she writes these words …	a man with a cart and bedding,		Luggage and grief			Wheeling and bumping				Singing a lonesome songWith this I see the opening scene of a movie. Sadly, I also see humanity as I see it nearly every day out in the world. I am always in awe when a poet of Slater’s stature so brilliantly captures so much in so few, but perfectly chosen words.These lines also resonated strongly with me, as I know they will with many:	Because home is home		the walls do speak		when we listenALSO:	And I was too generous		with sight		in seeing both sidesReading a gifted poet is a treat … and it is an experience that brings so much to the reader who is willing to dig deep, to remember, to feel. This is the epitome of my experience reading Wendy Slater’s work....more

title: Locked in Silence: A Novel
author: Dyen, Natalie Zellat*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Locked in Silence is a beautifully written, compelling, heartbreaking (and simultaneously uplifting) historical fiction novel. Lizzy O’Meara is a younLocked in Silence is a beautifully written, compelling, heartbreaking (and simultaneously uplifting) historical fiction novel. Lizzy O’Meara is a young woman who is incarcerated for murdering her newborn baby, a crime she vehemently denies having committed. Conditions are harsh as she serves her unjust four-year sentence in solitary confinement. Lizzy’s fortitude and strength, confronted with abuse and despair, diminish to the brink of insanity, where suicide appears to be the only way out. But after four years, she emerges back into the world. She is different, the world is different, yet so much of what she fought for remains the same. When she receives some shocking news about the supposed crime she committed, her world changes again.Author Dyen does a masterful job of capturing the courage and the strong will of a woman who has seen the worst, but presses on. Not only does Lizzy do what she can to right the personal wrongs in her life, she champions the abolitionist movement (fighting all of the ugliness that surrounds it) with unfailing determination that constantly tests her inner strength. This beautiful portrait of Lizzy O’Meara is also a touching love story—in more ways than one. Lizzy’s character was so very real to me in every way, and the events of pre-Civil War Philadelphia were superbly researched. An excellent novel indeed....more

title: A Trace of Romance
author: Swann, Ann*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Ann Swann is one of my favorite authors, and I’ve enjoyed her work across multiple genres for years. Her latest release, A Trace of Romance, is a trulAnn Swann is one of my favorite authors, and I’ve enjoyed her work across multiple genres for years. Her latest release, A Trace of Romance, is a truly sweet and extremely touching romance.I’m not a fan of romance novels with bare-chested men on the covers, but I am very much a fan of romance stories with well-developed characters who are relatable … flaws and all. Real people.I won’t recap the general plot in any detail as one can easily read the blurb. Rather, I’d just like to expound a bit on why I loved this beautifully written novella. So many of us can relate to past loves that for one reason or another, didn’t fully form into lifetime relationships … or continue to form at all. Life happens for all of us, and things can swiftly change. Especially when tragedy is involved. We move on, but often, we don’t forget. This is what happened with Laynie and Trace, both from the town of Beach Way, Oregon, who always thought they’d be together. What I loved about this story is that when Trace returns to Beach Way, and Laynie and he see one another again, their chemistry is strong. The past, which determined their present, still plays a role in their story. Author Swann doesn’t give us romance in a corny or clichéd sense, but she handles this reunion and this mutual love beautifully, realistically, and in a way that I found immensely satisfying and lovely to read....more

title: House Built on Fog & Sand: A Collection of Poems and Artwork
author: Arrigo, Anna Casamento
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: The Power of a WordSeveral years ago, I read a  of this book, put it on my TBR list, and have been waiting for a quiet moment to read and to savThe Power of a WordSeveral years ago, I read a  of this book, put it on my TBR list, and have been waiting for a quiet moment to read and to savor it. On a quiet Sunday, with the rain falling outside, I believe the mood was finally set.Anna Casemento Arrigo knows the power of a word. In many of these gorgeous poems, there is only one word per line. A gifted poet knows that one word must do so much to move forth the message, the scene, the inner thoughts, and the soul of the poet who has placed them just so.While I enjoy well-written poetry such as this, I never quite know how one s it adequately or accurately. So, as I read, I jotted down my thoughts, hoping they’d make sense as I came back to them. I read most of these poems twice to receive the full impact. And I so enjoyed the inclusion of artwork throughout, gently complementing the poetry. In the poem “god …” I discovered fantastic, thought-provoking imagery. In “Maria,” the sad, yet-for-some joy of going home was beautifully captured.There wasn’t one poem unworthy of its place in this collection. I loved “Dust Bowl” and “By the river” which paints a word portrait of an old man. Being a long-time admirer of artist Edvard Munch, I was delighted by the poem in his name. One of my favorites was “Leftover Crumbs,” a poignant and powerful description of a man at a bar. Another favorite, “No receipt,” compared unwanted and painful memories to old clothing being collected for donation. Superb! ...more

review: Having read the first two books by this author, I knew this story, like her other ones, would take off out of the gate and continue to deliver the actHaving read the first two books by this author, I knew this story, like her other ones, would take off out of the gate and continue to deliver the action, twists, and surprises until the very end.I’m not one to write s that merely recap a book. Rather, I like to share is what stood out and impacted me the most. I’ll only say that when crime novelist Sebastian Bartoli and kindergarten teacher Morgan Sklyar meet, the circumstances are beyond anything either could have imagined. Two people couldn’t meet in a more unconventional way and have less in common. Except … as Joy York does so well in this novel, is to show how very wrong initial appearances can be, and that the person who seems to be all wrong, can be very right. But when danger follows, survival is paramount.Adding to this, Sebastian (Bash) and Morgan both learn some shocking things about their respective family ties that are tough enough to deal with in “normal” times, much less when chaos chases them.Just when you think all has been revealed … well, I’ll leave that to the reader to discover. I especially recommend this book to fans of romantic suspense....more

title: Ignite Your Creativity: Simple & Easy Ideas - 99 Writing Prompts Included
author: Romes, Jan*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Author Jan Romes has chosen the perfect title for this book. While not claiming to be the foremost expert on the subject, this author who has written Author Jan Romes has chosen the perfect title for this book. While not claiming to be the foremost expert on the subject, this author who has written thirty books (fiction) with more on the way, and who has been an avid user of social media for years, has a lot of exceptionally good advice.First, while a seasoned writer might think, “I don’t need this,” one may be wrong. While Romes isn’t offering any shocking or wild techniques, what she does quite expertly is to remind writers (and other creatives) just how much inspiration is right in front of our eyes. She reminds every creative person to look at the nuances of everything that surrounds us—even at what one might consider mundane. It could be something we’ve seen or heard so many times that we fail to find value where a metaphoric treasure trove may exist.Second, this is a terrific resource for writers and other creatives or are just starting out and who may feel overwhelmed by all of the content, the rules, the writing books, and so much more. I do believe that this book can really help the author to organize their thoughts and better make use of inspiration that may seem invisible or out of reach. I would also highly recommend this book to anyone teaching creative writing. This would make a superb guide to teaching students of all ages.The author also talks briefly about language—learning new language and being mindful of which words work best for different genres. With 99 writing prompts, this couldn’t be more perfect for creative writing students or authors who need fresh ways to think. No matter where you are in life, we can all have days where we feel like a dead battery that needs recharging. And that’s where this book comes to the rescue. A gem....more

title: Sisters
author: Barrow, Judith
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Probably my favorite thing to read, no matter the genre, is well-written, character-driven fiction. And this is exactly what Judith Barrow excels at. Probably my favorite thing to read, no matter the genre, is well-written, character-driven fiction. And this is exactly what Judith Barrow excels at. This is the second book of hers that I’ve read. Having loved the first one, choosing Sisters was a no-brainer.This novel’s blurb offers an overview of the story as do many of the s. I don’t see any reason to recap the plotline. For one, it’s too delicious and best savored without knowing all that much. I shall only say this: the book is as the title says, about sisters. It begins in 1970, when a string of actions in a small slice of one day, spell tragedy and change the lives of sisters Mandy and Angela forever.Barrow’s evolution of the story is well plotted in a way that is so natural, she makes it look easy. As I read, gripped by this emotional story, I loved that it wasn’t predictable, yet reminded me so much of my own stories and those of others that have taken a path because of something that happened in moment in time, or because of a good or bad choice that we as humans make. I read this straight through over two days, not wanting to put it down. Not only is it a beautiful and compelling read, it was deeply satisfying. This is an author who truly understands human nature....more

review: LOVED this book!Admittedly, I read almost no fantasy, but I heard such good things about this book/author that I decided to give it a try. These five-LOVED this book!Admittedly, I read almost no fantasy, but I heard such good things about this book/author that I decided to give it a try. These five-star s don’t lie. The story, the writing, the insight, the lessons, the history, the thought-provoking power and everything else about this book is superb.The Seas of Time, telling the tale of how a wrecked ship in 1858 influences/melds with events in 1972, is fascinating. In the hands of a lesser author, I don’t believe this would have been the page-turning and brilliant read I found it to be. I was riveted. As the main character, Tali Keldan, makes friends with a gargoyle who is inhabiting her family’s Harbor Pointe Inn on the California coast (while she is there to keep an eye on things), I believed every word: the power of a great writer. And yes, we learn how the gargoyle came to be. It wasn’t difficult to imagine the scene and the action—as phantasmagorical as it all may sound in this .There is SO much more to this story, which goes way beyond the little I’ve divulged in the previous paragraph. This story, its impact, its meaning, the lessons it teaches, and the lessons society has yet to learn, are all packed in this gem of a book....more

review: Being a fan of paranormal stories, especially because I believe in many of them, I was intrigued to read this novel. First, it takes place in the 1980Being a fan of paranormal stories, especially because I believe in many of them, I was intrigued to read this novel. First, it takes place in the 1980s, but I must admit, I didn’t figure that out until I was halfway through the novel, when I realized that nobody had cell phones and that the story took place during a time when phones were for talking and cameras for taking photos. I thoroughly enjoyed the four young Canadian women travel who to the US for a vacation, but end up as far from what they imagined as possible—in a town called St. Clair steeped in mystery. For me, there were a lot of characters in this story (all good, but always tougher for me to focus), but everything came together.Front and center was a romance between Gabrielle and Rick, the sighting of a dead boy named Steven, and a mystery surrounding the town. I don’t like to write s that give away too much, but I was intrigued, and the camaraderie among the friends believable. The author did a great job of weaving the paranormal elements with the romantic ones and offering quite a satisfying ending....more

review: It’s been several years since I read a couple of books by this author, but what always stayed with me was that I could remember more from those novelsIt’s been several years since I read a couple of books by this author, but what always stayed with me was that I could remember more from those novels than I do from many I read. So, even though this book wasn’t next from where I left off, the premise of this new release intrigued me.Amanda Gale is a superb writer. But it takes more than well-written words to draw me into a book. Just as I remembered, this author excels at writing nuanced, flawed, believable, and often complex characters who twist themselves into emotional wrecks while simultaneously work to create happier versions of themselves. Human beings are complicated, and Gale knows how to authentically portray them. That much alone, for me, is a huge plus.The blurb for this book quite nicely tells prospective readers what the story is about. I’ll add only that Maeve in the Morning is a story of relationships, family, passions, secrets, love, longing, indecision, and the fine art of holding back. I really loved this story, and highly recommend this women’s fiction novel to sophisticated readers who appreciate the beautiful writing and characters who very well may be like you or those close to your heart. Lastly, despite this being part of a series, it works beautifully as a stand-alone novel....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m such a fan of the multi-author crime fiction series, Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles, having read many of the books so far. Years ago, I read and I’m such a fan of the multi-author crime fiction series, Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles, having read many of the books so far. Years ago, I read and enjoyed a novel by Joe Congel, so I was excited to see his contribution to the series.Reading most of this book in one sitting, I thoroughly enjoyed the story of Brandon Turner, a retired NYC police detective who comes to Magnolia Bluff with his dog, Max, to get far away from his former life and lead a quiet life. While the scenery drastically changes, Turner is immediately pulled back into the profession he just left when he discovers a body and finds out it wasn’t the first one. And the deaths don’t stop there. He’s hardwired to solve crimes and finds it tough to turn away. Simultaneously, he takes an instant liking to his real estate broker, Joyce, who can’t help but get wrapped up in all that’s going on.I loved Congel’s interaction between Turner and Reece Sovern. Although Turner isn’t officially on the case, he agrees to work with Magnolia Bluff’s police chief. They’re men from very different worlds, each with their own way of doing things, but who realize they need one another to solve the case. There are several different stories at play, and nothing is as simple as it seems. The author seamlessly weaves the different plots together into a very engaging story. This story was terrific, and I love seeing characters that I’ve come to know from the other books I’ve read. An excellent addition to a superb series. ...more

title: A Nightingale's Last Song: A WWII Romance
author: Harryman, Kathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Kathleen Harryman has outdone herself with this beautifully and authentically crafted novel. A Nightingale’s Last Song gives the reader a front-row seKathleen Harryman has outdone herself with this beautifully and authentically crafted novel. A Nightingale’s Last Song gives the reader a front-row seat to the courageous and committed nurses who served tirelessly and selflessly in WWII. It takes a special kind of person to endure the sight of death and dying every day, to process such pain and grief with no time to restore one’s strength, and to encourage those who struggle to recover in both body and spirit from the savagery of war. As Lillian Elizabeth performs her job, she meets two different men, Alick and Joe, each who has a piece of her heart, but in entirely different ways. The author has written a beautiful love story which I think will resonate with readers worldwide. It certainly did with me, as did the themes of friendship and family. I loved the way the story was tenderly and realistically presented, and I couldn’t have been more touched by the gorgeous way that everything was brought to a close. With every word I read, I was impressed by the staggering amount of research I knew the author must’ve done to create such a vivid and emotional story. I felt the same when I read her first historical fiction novel, The Promise, and I did so even more with this book. I highly recommend both. Exceptional work....more

review: First and most importantly: I LOVED this book, the third in Katie Oliver’s Jane Austen Tea Society Mystery series. Being a huge fan of the first two bFirst and most importantly: I LOVED this book, the third in Katie Oliver’s Jane Austen Tea Society Mystery series. Being a huge fan of the first two books, I couldn’t wait to read the third. It exceeded my expectations, which is tough to do.In this book, Phaedra Brighton, a Jane Austen scholar and English professor, is delighted when her younger sister returns home to open up a patisserie (Tout de Sweet) — adding a French bakery to the town of Laurel Springs. I won’t belabor the plot, only to say that it gets going quickly when a local celebrity’s assistant takes a bite from a poisonous cupcake and is rushed to the hospital, leaving no one the wiser as to who the intended victim is. And Phaedra, as she always does, refuses to leave this crime alone, especially as her sister’s reputation and new shop are both in jeopardy.Why did I love this book? So many reasons. It grabbed my attention immediately and was intriguing until the very end. Katie Oliver does a superb job of offering her readers a plethora of suspects and possibilities. The story was so brilliantly and beautifully crafted—with subplots that enhanced every page. Every dubious character has reason to be under scrutiny, but why? The motive is as elusive as the culprit. And the love stories woven through this book, they’re just the icing on … well, maybe not a cupcake … but some kind of cake. You decide.I highly recommend this book. I read it in two sittings. It’s a great story to lose yourself in and just get away from it all. Terrific series!...more

He’s semi-retired (working I thoroughly enjoyed this novel by John Dolan, his long-standing character, PI David Braddock once again in the spotlight. He’s semi-retired (working as a hypnotherapist) and living in London with his wife, Da, and their two children.Having read several of this author’s books, the first thing I noticed was his signature dry wit, always a staple in everything he writes. Although PIs retire, there’s nothing to say that their naturally inquisitive minds and urge to solve crimes do so as well. Especially when there’s not enough in one’s life to quite fill the empty space. So, when Braddock’s next-door neighbor, a dentist, is found murdered, each half of his body discovered in different locations, Braddock plunges back into the life he knew for a decade in Thailand.Almost immediately, at an alarming rate, Braddock finds way more mysteries than he bargained for, and despite the danger in following every lead, he’s back in the thick of things.Dolan’s skill in weaving together several mysteries is impressive. I really loved the inclusion of the abandoned London Underground in the novel. It was fascinating and complemented the story so very well. Great choice. Another excellent novel from this author. title: Dreamland: Banat, Crisana, Maramures, Transylvania, 100-WORD STORIES, Folklore and History
author: Furstenberg, Patricia*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: It often takes far more expertise and talent to write a very short story than a long one. And that’s the first thing that I noticed in this brilliant It often takes far more expertise and talent to write a very short story than a long one. And that’s the first thing that I noticed in this brilliant and beautiful book by Patricia Furstenberg. Every word of her 100-word stories is perfectly chosen and placed to tell a colorful, magical, and often phantasmagorical story, followed by a brief historical details that bring the legend/story full circle.“Her nose was not crooked and there were no warts on her face. Her voice didn’t crackle and she didn’t own a black cat.”“Building upon past generations’ resourcefulness, they invented complex mechanisms capable of decoding the mysteries of fleeting time.”The author’s words, like the quotes above, mesmerized and kept me reading vociferously as the sights, sounds, and legends of her beloved Romania came to life. As I read, I was entertained while simultaneously impressed by the massive amount of research I knew had to go into this book. Exceptional—as were the stunning photographs she collected.As the author states, this isn’t a history book, but a collection of fleeting impressions and more. Still, for readers who love Romania, for those who wish an introduction (like myself), and for historians / storytellers present and future, Dreamland is a treasure. As I read on, it occurred to me that sharing these stories with children would conjure as child’s imagination as vividly as they did mine.I highly recommend this extraordinary book....more

review: What an absolutely delightful weekend read this book proved to be. Having read a several books by this author before, including one in the Shell Isle What an absolutely delightful weekend read this book proved to be. Having read a several books by this author before, including one in the Shell Isle Mystery series, her new release called to me—and I’m so glad I answered it.When cousin sleuths Page and Betsy, owners of the Honey Bees Bake Shop, are hired to cater an afternoon for a group of English authors staying at the local Three Fables Inn, a murder stops them dead in their tracks when Page’s mysterious inklings lead her to find a bench-draped body in the elegant gardens. Oh, and there may be a ghost or two about. Hmm.The first words that come to mind in describing this book are “colorful and clever.” The characters are distinct, funny, eccentric and so much more. Penrose takes full advantage of the Shell Island setting and the local haunts. She whisks her readers off to enjoy Shell’s tropical delights while entertaining them in myriad ways. Of course, Page and Betsy, who never shy away from a good mystery, are hot on the trail of the killer.While Cousin Betsy is cooking up some questionable edible dishes, we learn the author has cooked up delicious sub-plots that weave through this wonderful story. I came to love her core characters even more, while my brain was quickly assessing the new ones, trying to figure out who had done what, who was on the level, and who might be fooling me until the very suspenseful end.There’s intrigue, humor, romance, mystery and so much more. The writing is excellent, and the book is a true day-brightener. ...more

review: I just loved this book. Having read several novels by this author, I’ve come to really love the aspects that define Tonya Penrose’s work. As soon as II just loved this book. Having read several novels by this author, I’ve come to really love the aspects that define Tonya Penrose’s work. As soon as I opened this story, I felt as if I were in the town of Port Royal. Through the main character, Halley Bowen’s eyes, I could see the beauty of the town, both from the outside and the inside. So picturesque, so charming, so believable.What I most appreciate about this author is that her characters, while having great senses of humor (except the annoying, quirky ones who don’t), is that they’re all seeking to enhance their respective lots in love and in life, whether they realize it or not. They’re open to the wisdom and enlightenment that surrounds them. But first and foremost, they’re flawed, relatable human beings who often fight the chance to elevate their lives until understanding comes to them.Indeed, I was intrigued by Halley Bowen being offered a wonderful life by an anonymous benefactor — in the beautiful seaside town of Port Royal — with one hitch. This premise was so different from anything I’d read before. What was the hitch? What could it be? Why was the benefactor making this offer? So many wonderful questions. Finally, I found the time to dive into this story.A Secret Gift is the perfect title for this book. Not only does Halley’s story deliver, but there are stories within the stories that were secret and unexpected gifts as well. A true gem of a book....more

Riley and Meg’s matchmaking service inside a Key West coffee shop is the perfect setting for love … most of the time.What is so interesting to me about the matchmaking service, is that even when two people are matched and the sparks don’t fly, that doesn’t necessarily mean the experience wasn’t valuable, often serving as a catalyst to help a person learn things about themselves to bring them closer to true love. This is a theme I’ve picked up on in all three of Jan Romes’s Coffee & Dessert novels. I Because the author touches on these nuances – it makes her characters all the more relatable. Another big plus for me in this book is seeing more of the characters in the first two books in this series, Meg and Danna. review: Joy York has written a wonderful Young Adult mystery story, set in the South in 1968. Lily, who is the jailer’s feisty and unafraid daughter, teams upJoy York has written a wonderful Young Adult mystery story, set in the South in 1968. Lily, who is the jailer’s feisty and unafraid daughter, teams up with her shy and insecure cousin Christi when they believe that a man being held in the local jail (attached to Lily’s house) is not guilty of the crime he’s accused of committing. Nothing is adding up for these young teens, and they’re determined to do the math.What I enjoyed so much in this novel is York’s wonderful characters. Lily and Christi’s fierce determination to accomplish what no one could expect they could do. Why let age, conventional wisdom, or common sense get in the way of solving a crime? So what if you’re only fourteen?York does a terrific job of transporting her readers to another era. The difference in her characters’ personalities was well-crafted and well-defined … adding more tension and authenticity to the story. The girls were age appropriate in every way … putting on a brave face and trying to hide their fear at the same time.Aside from a great story, I loved the coming-of-age aspects and the evolution of the friendship between the two cousins, who come to know and appreciate one another in a new light.Kudos to Ms. York on a well-told tale....more

title: Old Mountain Cassie: The Three Lessons
author: Penrose, Tonya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Old Mountain Cassie by Tonya Penrose has so many gifts; it’s hard to know where to begin. Set in the picturesque Appalachian village of Divine, this eOld Mountain Cassie by Tonya Penrose has so many gifts; it’s hard to know where to begin. Set in the picturesque Appalachian village of Divine, this exquisite novel follows Lacey Jordan’s quest to meet the mountain sage she’s heard so much about—and to whom she feels a magnetic pull toward. Penrose skillfully unfolds the story of these two women meeting, but also tells the tale of several other Divine residents and visitors. The plot alone, powerful in its magical qualities, though written about fictional characters, offers a road map of sorts to readers seeking to understand their own lives and the power that each of us might harness to have a hand in crafting our respective journeys. The way the characters’ choices and destinies merge is absolutely brilliant. The author offers insight and, perhaps, new ways to divine our lives, but is never preachy. And that alone is pure gold.Cassie is a spirited, spiritual, and delightful character. She chats with her “growin’ things’ and has an otherworldly connection with animals and nature. Her wisdom is grand, yet quietly offered. She is relatable, especially when she recognizes that Lacey is “afraid of newness and afraid of sameness.” I can’t speak for other readers, but this is a truth I’ve long held, which only gives more credence to Cassie’s sagacity. Another aspect of this book I really appreciated was Penrose’s careful balance between wisdom and outright humor. There was no shortage of funny (and yes, maddening!) moments with Lacey and her meddlesome aunt Gabby. The dialogue was very real, never overdone, and served to make this book all the more special. I truly loved everything about this wonderful novel....more

review: I’ve really been wanting to read this author’s work, having heard great things, so when I saw she had a brand new book out, I decided The Oath would bI’ve really been wanting to read this author’s work, having heard great things, so when I saw she had a brand new book out, I decided The Oath would be a perfect choice. I absolutely loved this story. The word “unputdownable” is often exaggerated, but that’s truly how I felt. I read this in two days, taking time to absorb the story and all of the wonderful characters.Taking place at the very end of the 19th century, this story centers around Françoise, who is forced/compelled into marrying her distant cousin, Charles, in England, because of a family oath made one-hundred years ago. And that’s all I want to say about the specifics of the story, because Osborne’s storytelling is superb, and I wouldn’t want to deprive potential readers of not experiencing the story for themselves.I loved Françoise’s character because she was a strong-willed, yet vulnerable young woman. I loved how she was caught between what was deemed the right thing to do in the late 1890s vs. what she felt in her heart—even when she wasn’t sure what her heart was telling her.The book alternates points of view between Françoise and Tilly, who becomes her best friend. The older women in the book, more “wed” to traditions of the time, often frustrated me as I’m sure they would’ve had I lived in those times. Osborne did a wonderful job of portraying the society and its norms, expectations, and hierarchy. From page one, I was immediately invested in the characters. I cared about them and never stopped. A truly excellent book by a great author! Highly recommend!...more

When I read her other Christmas book, A Crossbow Christmas, I remember being left with a happy feeling on what had been a difficult time for me. Recently, I just happened to see she had another Christmas story out, and for me, it didn’t matter what time of the year it is, I knew I would enjoy it.I was so right. This was such a lovely story, and I found it extremely relatable. By that, I don’t mean that the reader need go through what Swann’s character Miranda (Randi) was going through, but relatable in the sense of what one feels when that she/he has closed a chapter that needed slamming shut, no matter what one’s dreams were, and being able to recognize that something much better awaits—that chances are worth taking.I should add that I absolutely loved that Randi worked in a veterinary office. Animals in a story are always a big plus for me. Swann’s writing and characterizations are always real to me … funny … and worth reading. review: This beautifully written collection of short stories reeled me in from the first story, “End of the Road,” reminding me that happy endings can appear This beautifully written collection of short stories reeled me in from the first story, “End of the Road,” reminding me that happy endings can appear when you least expect them. I really loved “The Dolphin.” In only a few pages, the story went somewhere unexpected, but brought forth thoughts and beliefs that I welcomed. I found it special as I believe many others will too: I’ll say no more.“Lyrical Dragon” like many of these stories in this collection, is filled with phantasmagorical elements that when looked at, hold so many truths. So many of the stories have simple lessons, yet are told in a way that reminds the reader how many different ways there are to look at life—and death, and that the world gives us so many messages—in every form imaginable.As an animal lover, “The Bench” particularly appealed to me, but I loved seeing dogs, cats, and nature in general in so many of the stories.“Deadline” was another favorite. I felt as if I’d been transported into a horror movie – one I believe could really happen. “The Day the Ground Moved,” all within a few pages, was scary in imaginable and unimaginable ways.This  will be too long if I continue with all of the notes I made. I'll end by saying that Finn’s writing is excellent, creative, and will definitely offer new perspectives. I enjoyed the stories of all lengths....more

review: The concept of a gift is deceptively simple. It’s something we’re given, supposedly to bring us pleasure, whether we actually like it or not. We have The concept of a gift is deceptively simple. It’s something we’re given, supposedly to bring us pleasure, whether we actually like it or not. We have gifts for specific talents, which are almost always welcome, but spiritual gifts can be a very different thing. They’re complex, daunting, and fascinating—uniquely appreciated (or not) by each person who possesses them.What I really enjoyed about this book was the author’s story of how the gift of being a soul shepherd has impacted a family, most especially two sisters, Elise and Sarah, whose gifts have affected them both, but not with identical consequences. Are those who are given gifts fated to have them forever? Is there an expiration date if the recipient wants there to be? Can that person co-exist with the unwanted gift, or can one rid themselves of it … and how?Cathleen Maza always gives her readers so very much to think about. review: This is one of the most excellent short story collections I’ve read. After finishing the first story, which went somewhere I never expected, I knew thThis is one of the most excellent short story collections I’ve read. After finishing the first story, which went somewhere I never expected, I knew that I was really going to enjoy this author. She has great insight into human nature, but also, as is evident in all of her work, she has a keen eye for observation.The subjects of the stories have many tales to tell, from a woman who decides to speak as little as possible, to a woman railing against her neighbor, an over-tanning trophy wife/widow, to a poignant story about a reporter developing a friendship with an obese woman. There is a car that seems to have a particular personality, a man at the end of his life who speaks through a synthesizer, and an art student who is “perplexed” by the demands of her professor … and so many more. The last story, which gave me a chill similar to the first one … makes a second and brilliant bookend in this collection. Oh, and there was a poem called “Dot” which I found exceptional and spot on. But I won’t give that away.The writing is superb, and the situations and characters are clearly from a writer who understands human nature and how it can evolve or devolve. There wasn’t one story that didn’t move me emotionally in some way, and every story compelled me to wonder what inspiration gave birth to it.If you’re looking for well-written, illuminating, and character-driven fiction, I highly recommend this collection....more

review: This novel by Richard Schwindt, which is 14th in the multi-genre-author crime series, Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles, is excellent, and is also the sThis novel by Richard Schwindt, which is 14th in the multi-genre-author crime series, Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles, is excellent, and is also the second contribution from this author, whom I’ve followed for many years.The premise is fascinating: dead male psychologists are being found dead in a field, and Schwindt’s character, Dr. Michael Kurelek, also a psychologist, is not only keen to figure out what is happening and why, but also has no idea if he too is a target.I try very hard not to offer the prospective reader a mere synopsis, but rather, a brief insight into why I keep returning to this author and so enjoy his work.The author, in every novel, uses his training and vast experience as a social worker and therapist to craft realistic, funny, tragic, flawed, and empathetic characters: a staple in every book he writes. What makes this mystery particularly intriguing is that it’s not just a “whodunit,” but a “whytheydunit.” Schwindt’s dialogue always takes me right into the scene; I feel more like a fly on the wall than a reader. The characters’ words sound effortless and real. I particularly loved the inclusion of the character’s parents into this story, which served to give it even more depth.Another great read in this superior series! title: Letter from a Cave: The Mystery of a Letter found in a Cave in the Swiss Mountains Uncovers a Heartbreaking Love Story during World War II
author: Polkinhorn, Christa*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’ve read several of this author’s books over the years, and I was very happy to learn she had a new release, one that gives new adventures to establiI’ve read several of this author’s books over the years, and I was very happy to learn she had a new release, one that gives new adventures to established characters. It’s always great to see old friends. That said, this wonderful book doesn’t rely on past novels to be enjoyed. Sculptor Andreas, who has been lonely and depressed since his wife’s death three years prior, often hikes into the mountains. One day, while with his dog in a cave, he is surprised when the dog unearths a backpack from years ago. Looking inside, Andreas finds a letter from an Italian man named Joshua to his pregnant wife, Bella during World War II. He realizes Joshua never made it home and his family most likely never knew what happened to him or that he had tried to make contact.The emotional weight of the letter hits Andreas hard, and with the encouragement of his daughter, Emilia, and his son, Tonio, he sets off to Italy to see if he can do the impossible and track down Bella (if she’s still alive) or other family members. Tonio takes his sister and father to a vineyard in Tuscany where he has a friend, Julietta. Readers of the author’s previous book will remember Julietta and her mother, Luisa, from The Italian Sister.From this point on, the story really takes off. I don’t want to summarize the plot, but rather offer a short commentary on why I found this book to be so special. Author Polkinhorn has several wonderful and heartfelt sub-plots flowing through the main story. All of them are skillfully woven together, beautifully emulating life and its twisty, unpredictable ways. I genuinely cared about every character. Letter from a Cave offers suspense, romance, emotion, surprises, nostalgia, and so much more. The author’s gorgeous descriptions made it easy to visualize the scenes in Switzerland and Italy—not to mention making me hungry for Italian food. This was truly a feel-good read, and I hope the author will continue to write more stories with her delightful characters. Already, I’m wondering how they’re all doing....more

review: Having read several of this author’s memoirs—and all of her novels, for a long time, I’d been eager to read one of her earlier memoirs about her 20 yeHaving read several of this author’s memoirs—and all of her novels, for a long time, I’d been eager to read one of her earlier memoirs about her 20 years in South Africa. For anyone who is interested in what life was like in and around Johannesburg, Valerie Poore brilliantly provides not only a colorful overview, but zeroes in on the many areas in which she and her family lived, detailing each city’s unique traits — the good, the bad, and the well, unfortunate. The author’s beautiful writing, as in her others books, draws the reader in as if one has almost been teleported to each location. Her attention to detail is mesmerizing, but never boring. I can’t stress strongly enough how well this author recreates a scene—even with the fine detailing of car and bicycle mishaps. Humor is prevalent throughout the book, serving to make the stories all the more charming.For someone who isn’t keen on moving, I was amazed by the moving of house five times in this book’s time span alone. Not only did the family pack up and move, but they renovated homes and made major adaptations to their previous ways of living — something I found to be very impressive. I learned so much about the various cities, what it was like to work, what it was like for her daughters, and so much more. Being an animal lover, I was heartened by the many stories about animals and pets. I was fascinated by many of the author’s descriptions, and as I read, I did much Internet research – from the upside down Baobab trees to Velvet Monkeys in a Zimbawbe trees. I was saddened to read about schoolchildren begging not for money—but for pens and paper. Having read much about this author’s life on a barge based in Rotterdam, I was especially interested to learn how she went from living in South Africa to the Netherlands—and I understand so well by her former country is so dear to her heart.If you’re interested in life in South Africa, especially during turbulent political times, you may find this book every bit as fascinating as I did. Brava!...more

What I really liked about this novel by Vicky Whedbee is the insight she has into human emotions, how people are pulled in so many directions, and that no matter how much we struggle to do the right thing, the answers are never easy. title: Venetian Rhapsody
author: Penrose, Tonya*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having read two books by this author before, I knew I was going to truly enjoy this one. I just had no idea how much, nor for how many reasons.When SoHaving read two books by this author before, I knew I was going to truly enjoy this one. I just had no idea how much, nor for how many reasons.When Sofia Martin from Boston and Eduardo Diaz from Spain, both meet in Venice, the City of Love, as a reader might expect, the attraction and the chemistry are instant, as are the obstacles. That’s all I want to say about the story line, because what this author delivered went so far beyond all of my expectations (and I expected to thoroughly enjoy the book!) As I read, I had no idea where the story was going. And that was exactly what I loved about it. First, the characters were real, and while they walked a path together, destiny made sure they walked their own paths as well. The author has a deep and spiritual understanding of the human psyche: what propels it forward and what yanks it back. She always understands that each love story is unique, requiring every soul to chart their own course. Both Sofia and Eduardo found magic and “unexplainables” in their journey to find love, but as they both learned, that alone does not guarantee a happy ending.Author Penrose has written a beautiful story that is simultaneously steeped in the veracity of human nature and both the visible and invisible guides that help us through this journey called life. Her characters were extremely real to me, neither invulnerable to tripping and falling on the way to love. Where I expected the story to go “right,” it went “left,” making it that much more beguiling to me. As I read, I stopped myself from trying to second guess the outcome; I just went along for the ride.Aside from the characters, Penrose did a superb job of bringing the characters’ surroundings to life. If you’ve never been to Venice, expect to visit for the first time. If you’ve been before, expect a “return trip.”This is an exceptional love story — an exceptional story about life and love.**Ordinarily, my  would end here. But this is no ordinary novel. It is a collaboration of Ms. Penrose’s words and composer David Bazo’s music. While one need not have the companion CD to enjoy this novel, I highly recommend it. I listened to the CD over and over throughout my entire read, and it was such a beautiful, soul-lightening, and elevating experience. I highly recommend both: a magical collaboration indeed.**...more

Taylor’s main character, Tom (Harrison), a renowned horseman, is front and center in this tale. He’s a well-drawn character, flawed, determined, inquisitive, and so much more. review: This is the first book I’ve read by D.G. Kaye, but as soon as I read the first few pages, I knew it wouldn’t be the last. There was so much I could idThis is the first book I’ve read by D.G. Kaye, but as soon as I read the first few pages, I knew it wouldn’t be the last. There was so much I could identify with in the blurb, so on a whim, I downloaded it. The issue of self-esteem, which the author speaks so knowingly about, is one that affects more people than I believe most of us even realize. Low self-esteem manifests itself in many ways and that can make it more difficult for some to see. Yet, I believe it visits a preponderant number of people at some point in their lives, if not throughout. Reading this book was like talking to a new friend and sharing common experiences. Kaye’s uplifting yet honest writing style makes it very easy to turn the pages.Even with the issues that I hadn’t personally experienced, I knew many who did (and still do), and I really appreciated Kaye’s down-to-earth approach to examining these issues and offering simple, relatable advice for those seeking to better their lives. As I especially connected to some aspects of the author’s relationship with her mother, I’m absolutely planning to read her book Conflicted Hearts. Our situations, while very different, are also very similar in ways.Kaye discusses subjects in this book that took me back years and also resonated with me in the present. There are many reasons that I would recommend this book. Not only do I appreciate the common-sense advice, but I believe the author’s words are extraordinarily validating and will help many who feel alone in their pain. This book is also beautifully written. Excellent....more

review: Being a human is tough. There are a lot of problems in this world to solve, much less to understand. Then there’s Robbie. He’s plodding along, doing hBeing a human is tough. There are a lot of problems in this world to solve, much less to understand. Then there’s Robbie. He’s plodding along, doing his best living a pretty ordinary life. Then meets someone who he learns is an “old friend” and tells Robbie is name is Thor and that they’re both from another galaxy. Robbie learns he was sent to Earth years ago to make sense of human emotions and feelings. An easy task, right? Not so much. With the help of his galactic friends, who are far from experts on human beings, Robbie resolves to stay a while longer and fulfill his goal of better understanding humans. He invites three homeless friends into his life and the lessons begin.The author has penned quite an intriguing, thought-provoking novel to open a reader’s mind to the complexities of human nature and how they might be perceived by non-earthlings: something most of us probably don’t think about very much, if ever. After all, it’s tough for humans to understand our own emotions: imagine pondering the same questions being from another galaxy. How do we succeed? Why do we fail? How. Much control do we really have? What’s it like to develop feelings for others? To help others? The questions are endless and the answers aren’t always apparent. Author Bazinet thoughtfully presents so very much for the reader to ponder as she gives us characters to care about. A special book....more

title: Genuine Deceit
author: York, Joy*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: This was an amazing story that just kept going—giving the reader more and more to ponder.When Reagan Asher’s grandmother is murdered in her modest homThis was an amazing story that just kept going—giving the reader more and more to ponder.When Reagan Asher’s grandmother is murdered in her modest home in Ohio, she is wholly unprepared for what follows the tragic event. Everything she thought she knew about her life, her identity, her family, and everything else, unravels before her eyes. Simultaneously, she is questioning her current relationship with Tyler, her boyfriend back in Chicago, as her best friend’s brother-in-law, Aiden, appears on the scene and takes center stage in her heart. But how can she judge anything in the state that she’s in? Who can she trust?As soon as one question is answered, another is asked. Then another and another. It’s like being in a maze of fun-house mirrors where nothing is what it appears to be. There is threat after threat and mystery after mystery. Will it ever resolve?Joy York has skillfully plotted a story of deceit that spans the years and is complex and action-packed from beginning to end. I not only enjoyed the suspense aspect of this novel, but Reagan’s evolution as a young woman struck a chord with me. Ms. York did an excellent job of zeroing in on the complexities of human nature and bringing to life relatable, flawed characters that readers can identify with. A thoroughly enjoyable novel....more

title: Fat Dogs and Welsh Estates
author: Haslam, Beth*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Where to begin? Having read one the first book in this author’s Fat Dogs and French Estates series (can’t wait to read more), I was intrigued by this Where to begin? Having read one the first book in this author’s Fat Dogs and French Estates series (can’t wait to read more), I was intrigued by this prequel, eager to learn more about the woman who had so many wonderful tales to share about her life in France.As it turns out, the girl who grew up in Wales was every bit as fascinating. I know people with many different childhood stories, but Beth Haslam’s was truly unlike anything I’ve heard before. With each chapter, I couldn’t help but imagine how many children’s series could have been developed from just her life alone: Her family, animals, school adventures, sailing, castle-living, and so much more. Not only is this memoir enchanting, but it is so beautifully written that it just draws the reader in.This memoir not only tells of a magical childhood, but the historic value of this book, in my opinion, should not be overlooked. Haslam takes great care to share her Welsh heritage with readers, from proverbs to language to pronunciation of those very easy-to-pronounce (not!) Welsh words. I couldn’t help but think that I hope this book will be read by generations to come: there is so very much to be learned and appreciated.I found this book to be enlightening, entertaining, and rich in detail. This was a labor of love. It’s clear how much effort the author put into the writing, especially having to go back decades to bring the past to life again. Truly delightful. I just loved it....more

review: Phaedra Brighton, a college professor with expertise in Jane Austen, is a wonderful main character, and the perfect unintentional sleuth in this terriPhaedra Brighton, a college professor with expertise in Jane Austen, is a wonderful main character, and the perfect unintentional sleuth in this terrific series by Katie Oliver. Like the first book in this series, Pride, Prejudice, and Peril, there’s a really well-plotted cozy mystery with lots of charm, humor and no shortage of suspects. It’s beautifully and intelligently written, and there’s such wonderful (and believable) repartee between the characters. Phaedra, trying to save her aunt Wendy’s inn, hosts an immersive Persuasion-themed mystery event – taking place over a weekend. When a guest is actually found dead, the search for a killer becomes the real deal. What makes this such an engaging book is that Katie Oliver gives her reader so much more than a simple whodunit. Not only was I fascinated by the clues and possibilities, there are so many relationships between characters who I found myself truly caring about.I was captivated from beginning to end: evaluating clues, wondering how the personal stories would play out, and simply enjoying the exceptional storytelling. review: What a terrific story! This is the third book in the Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles that I’ve read, and the first novel by this author, who I chose aWhat a terrific story! This is the third book in the Magnolia Bluff Crime Chronicles that I’ve read, and the first novel by this author, who I chose after reading one of his short stories in the anthology, Beyond the Sea: Stories from the Underground.The authors of this series have created a wonderful fictional town in Texas, Magnolia Bluff, with colorful, disparate characters that readers won’t soon forget and do an excellent job of maintaining consistency with each unique story.In Eulogy in Black and White, murders have been committed for nine years straight, all on May Twenty Third. Although it’s clear that the same person is killing people, each murder has its own signature. Each person is killed as they were for a very specific reason … one of importance to the killer … and there doesn’t seem to be any logical connection. When the enigmatic Graham Huston comes to town, accepting a job to clean up at the newspaper, this man of few words, who has never written a newspaper story, soon finds himself pulled into the mystery of the May Twenty Third killer. Caleb Pirtle is a superb storyteller. This novel has wit, intrigue, heart, depth, truth, and a very clever resolution. Well done!...more

review: This was a beautifully written novel of some depth set in Malaya in the 1950s, a time and a place I’ll admit to knowing almost nothing about. That saiThis was a beautifully written novel of some depth set in Malaya in the 1950s, a time and a place I’ll admit to knowing almost nothing about. That said, while I still have much to understand, what I did draw from this novel was a time in history fraught with danger, wavering loyalties, uncertainty around every corner, and profound sadness. John Dolan easily draws the reader into another world with this exceptional historical fiction.I was intrigued by the character of Edward Braddock who had come from England to work on his uncle’s rubber plantation, with no desire to return as his family wished him to do. Written in the first person, Braddock is unapologetically honest and no one is more aware of his shortcomings than he is. Reading this story, I felt Braddock was as real as a character gets. I don’t want to give anything away, but I especially enjoyed his personal/family story—never once knowing what would happen or how the character would respond to the many events in his life. But I ended this book knowing this man as best as anyone can. I’ve read several books by this author. He is an supremely talented writer and I highly recommend this novel. ...more

title: You're the Ooze, Darlin'
author: Testerman, Jemimah*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Wow! What a book!When I picked up this book, I wasn’t prepared for how honest, raw, real, and gripping it would be. The author has lived through so muWow! What a book!When I picked up this book, I wasn’t prepared for how honest, raw, real, and gripping it would be. The author has lived through so much in her young life, and to say that I applaud her bravery in writing this memoir would be a vast understatement. She is not only helping herself in what has to be a long recovery process, but I have no doubt this book will help others in ways even the author has not imagined.I read a lot of books. This is the first memoir I’ve read written by someone only in her mid-twenties. But Ms. Testerman has a wisdom and a soul far older than her physical years. She also has a natural writing ability. This is not a long, drawn-out memoir. The author instinctively knows what matters and what doesn’t. Every line gets to the point and packs a punch—one you may physically feel for a long time. It’s that intense.While reading this, certain parts took my breath away. As the disclaimer in the beginning of the book states, the author “talks about sexual abuse, self-harm, suicide, and heavy drug and alcohol use.” This is not to be taken lightly. While I highly recommend this book, I recommend it only to those who are prepared and able to read it NOW. I believe this book has the ability to help so many people. A person need not have lived a life similar to Ms. Testerman’s to find solace, hope, and help in this book. This is for anyone who is suffering so intensely that they believe life cannot be lived without a great deal of pain … without thoughts of ending that life. It is also for anyone who wants to grasp even a basic understanding of what others go through, for those anyone who may wish to expand their knowledge or understand a loved one … and so much more. I hope this talented author will write more about her life and recovery, but only when she feels the time is right. This is a compelling read. Brava for writing it. Well done!...more

review: Seven years is a long time to be estranged from family, but without any money or life to speak of, Jamie eagerly returns home to Shellcombe Bay after Seven years is a long time to be estranged from family, but without any money or life to speak of, Jamie eagerly returns home to Shellcombe Bay after his uncle dies. Along with his brother, Matt, and his sister, Ashley, he’s inherited a once-booming resort that’s as rundown as Jamie feels. While the best option is to fix the place up, it’s a discomfiting proposition for the three siblings. Aside from the seven long years of absence, Matt and Ashley are both dealing with family issues, and while Jamie hasn’t brought many possessions with him, he’s got a lot of unseen baggage. Once the siblings decide to renovate the resort, the story kicks into high gear. Aside from all that’s happening with the adults, their children are facing their own battles. Jamie and his nephew, Simon have something in common besides blood: they’re both being blamed for things they haven’t done—by not-so-nice people who want revenge.Having read several of this author’s others books, I know she’s great at turning up the heat and kicking her stories into high gear. review: So much to say … I’m not sure where to begin.Sally Cronin’s latest collection of poetry and short stories is one of the most delightful that I’ve readSo much to say … I’m not sure where to begin.Sally Cronin’s latest collection of poetry and short stories is one of the most delightful that I’ve read. First, the poetry. While reading this book, I took notes on every poem, jotting down how I felt and what impressions it gave me. However, now that I’m writing a , I am finding it difficult to put those notes into one paragraph and make any cohesive sense. So let me try this another way.What I loved most about the poetry is the author’s gift for nuanced descriptions of nature and its creatures as if we’re seeing them with brand new eyes. Her poem “The Robin – Size doesn’t matter” really resonated with me. In my childhood, robins were abundant where I lived, but reading this poem felt as though I was meeting them anew, just as I felt reading about bees, butterflies, starlings and other creatures. The author is brilliantly observant and knows how to extract what is most special about the world she sees. And I love the pieces of art she creates with her lines of poetry. Most clever.I don’t want to give too much away about the short stories, but each one delighted me in a different way. I especially loved “The Secret” and wanted it to go on. But to summarize, all of the stories had connections with nature woven throughout – and I found each one to be touching and heartwarming. ...more

review: I love Ann Swann’s books. No matter what genre she writes in, her plots are always believable, layered, thought-provoking, engaging, and beautifully wI love Ann Swann’s books. No matter what genre she writes in, her plots are always believable, layered, thought-provoking, engaging, and beautifully written. This book was no exception.When Carina recovers from a serious bout with Covid, after being hospitalized and on a ventilator, she is left feeling out of sorts. Her husband is working insane hours and her children are living their lives in other cities. When Carina joins an online grief group, she makes an instant connection with a young man named Max, who lost his young wife to cancer. When he offers Carina the chance to spend Christmas at his family cabin in Crossbow, Colorado, it sounds like a dream. Getting her family to join her seems pretty much impossible, but does that mean she shouldn’t go?This novel is way more than a feel-good Christmas story. Swann explores family dynamics, a woman’s self-doubt and simultaneous determination, and twists and turns that mirror real life in ways that I suspect most readers will find extraordinarily relatable. I honestly didn’t know how this story would end because I felt the author’s in-depth writing could have taken it in many directions. This is the first time I’ve ever read a book in one sitting. Ann Swann drew me in … and I just had to know how this very special story ended. ...more

review: Romance writer Lucy Bretton’s long engagement to Wyatt Damschroder, one that felt like it would never turn into a marriage, has worn her out. Giving hRomance writer Lucy Bretton’s long engagement to Wyatt Damschroder, one that felt like it would never turn into a marriage, has worn her out. Giving him back his ring, at least for the time being, she heads off to Cranberry Creek, Massachusetts, hoping that inspiration for her next novel … a Christmas romance … will find her. Because she’s sure not finding inspiration from Wyatt … to say the least.Feeling anything but romantic, Lucy departs from the Big Apple to snowy to charming Cranberry Creek. Once there, driving her rental car, she and the handsome Logan Gabriel (in his car) “bump into each other.” After the snowy, but damage-free “collision” ends, he insists on leading Lucy to her the resort she’s booked into. Oh, yeah, one that conveniently forgot to say was owned by his parents.And here the story begins. While the attraction is immediate for both of them, Logan has an ex who’s trying to win him back, and Lucy is still engaged to Wyatt. Then there’s the fact that Logan lives in Ohio and Lucy in New York City. And so much more!Author Jan Romes, in her signature witty style, has adeptly strung together, like a perfect string of cranberries, a delightful story to warm readers’ hearts. All of the elements for a special Christmas story are present. Some readers may even want to jump into the book to partake in the festivities … and maybe even settle in Cranberry Creek. I thoroughly enjoyed this book. This is perfect take-me-away story and although it’s a Christmas story, it’s one that will delight year-round. ...more

review: Having read and enjoyed several of this author’s books, I couldn’t wait to delve into this book in this new multi-author crime series. Just as Hawes’sHaving read and enjoyed several of this author’s books, I couldn’t wait to delve into this book in this new multi-author crime series. Just as Hawes’s other reads, I was immediately drawn into the story. In Magnolia Bluff, the Crimson Hat Society has a prominent place in the town’s society. But as exists in most groups, there are power struggles, grudges, and yes, secrets. Oh, yes … and did I mention murder? And attempted murder?Harry Thurgood, who has left his past behind for a quiet life, has deep feelings for the Reverend Ember Cole … who has also left her past behind. Caring about her as he does, there’s no way he’s going to let her take the fall when a member of the Hat society is murdered and another is run down by a car. What I really enjoyed about this book was the author’s sharp storytelling and how adeptly he created a world of crafty and fascinating people. While these characters are so far from people I know, as humans, we still have much in common. Emotions, fears, unresolved anger, jealousy, and much more … can be life-changing. Few people can truly leave the past behind … and many cannot cope with the present. The tension in Magnolia Bluff stayed with me throughout the story … and as the characters revealed more and more about themselves, the intrigue grew … and I lost count of the number of surprises that revealed themselves. I loved the main characters and I know they have amazing stories untold in this novel. I hope to read them one day.An excellent book!...more

title: Beneath A Copper Sky
author: Poore, Valerie*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I’m such a fan of Valerie Poore’s writing. Truth be told, I’ve never read a book of hers – whether it be a memoir or a novel — that I didn’t find to bI’m such a fan of Valerie Poore’s writing. Truth be told, I’ve never read a book of hers – whether it be a memoir or a novel — that I didn’t find to be an absolutely delightful and beautifully written book. I haven’t yet read her three-book African Ways series, so I was really excited to finally be reading this novel that I knew would reflect her twenty years in South Africa from 1981 to 2001. Beneath a Copper Sky begins with an extraordinary word painting of two people, Angela and Stephen, as they leave England for a job in South Africa as caretakers for a remote farm … a brand-new and enchanting world where slow immersion into a new culture and environment, in a time of political turbulence, is not an option. The author’s talent for capturing the scenery, showing us the culture shock (yet love at first sight) from the characters’ point of view, and putting the reader right into the scene is absolutely brilliant. As Angela and Stephen work hard to acclimate to their new life, tension and unrest surround them. I could empathize and as I tried imagine what it must have been like to meet so many new people, all with very different stations in life, and try to figure out who to trust … and who to be wary about. In situations like this book relates … dark can seem light and light can seem dark.In every  I write, it’s important for me to express what I took from a book, never to recap the plot … I leave that for the readers. I not only thoroughly enjoyed this book, but I also learned more about the racial oppression (apartheid) that was a part of this country for far too many years. Kudos to the author for another engaging and fascinating story. As always, Ms. Poore teaches me so much and I look forward to more of her books. I truly do!...more

title: Cold Blows the Wind
author: Meyrick, Catherine*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I read a lot of books, but it’s not that often I think about them in my non-reading time and look forward to the late evening when I can get back to tI read a lot of books, but it’s not that often I think about them in my non-reading time and look forward to the late evening when I can get back to the story. Cold Blows the Wind is one of those books that embedded itself in my heart and wouldn’t let go.Ellen Thompson was the epitome of a strong woman … and true strength, to me, shines the brightest when one is poor, when life is unfair, when one is mistreated, and when dreams die unfulfilled. All of this and much more describes Ellen, yet she managed to take care of herself, her children, and her loved ones in the way she best could … always standing up for who she was. This historical story, which begins in Hobart Town, Australia in 1878, is rich in color and character … offering much insight into the lives of the poor and the harsh and often brutal living and societal conditions that were the norm. I did not know until I had read the entire book that it was based on the author’s great-great grandparents and their families. (While this is stated in the blurb, I only read the first paragraph when I purchased it.)I have no wish to give away any of the story, but Ellen’s character and her story resonated strongly with me. I was fascinated to read the historical notes at the end of the book, and I am impressed by all I can imagine Catherine Meyrick put into telling/researching this fragile, yet very human tale. She has combined history and fiction to produce a truly wonderful book. ...more

review: This was a lighthearted and delightful book. Having recently read and enjoyed a book by this author, Welcome to Charm, I took a look to see what else she’d written and found a newly published third book in a cozy mystery series.As someone who loves beach/island settings, colorful Shell Isle called to me. The two cousins, Page and Betsy, amateur sleuths always ready to solve a mystery, looked like the perfect people to hang out with … if only for the duration of this book. (And possibly more in the future!)I don’t like to give plots away in s, but rather tell prospective readers what I liked. First, what really appealed to me was the way the mystery began and just kept going. The characters were spunky, feisty, and funny … and I loved the dialogue and the interactions between friends, between sleuths and suspects, and on and on. I really felt the tension in the story and didn’t want to stop. Every time I thought the book was going “right,” it veered “left.” Truly … a lot of fun.I also enjoyed Page and Betsy’s love interests … and the antics and humor around Betsy’s bad cooking were hilarious. There are some recipes at the very end … and one I actually plan to try!If you’re looking for an upbeat read that will keep you guessing as you hang out with an interesting collection of disparate characters … I highly recommend this clever book....more

my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: Having read and enjoyed work by this author over the years, it was a treat to see she’d just released a new short story, “The Gift.”From a young age, Having read and enjoyed work by this author over the years, it was a treat to see she’d just released a new short story, “The Gift.”From a young age, Noah could see tattoos on the foreheads of other people … tattoos that revealed a great deal about the person … but being able to do so wasn’t necessary a good thing, esp. as his compassion pulled him toward people who weren’t always so nice. And, as a child, he didn’t want to stand out or be taunted for being different … especially in a way nobody would ever understand.While this is a short story and not a novel, the symbolism and meaning were quite thought-provoking. There are so many of us who have gifts/abilities that feel like burdens … or at the very least … nuisances. Noah’s path to learning that he has a gift, not burden … is a powerful one that resonated strongly with me as I believe it will with others.This book also included two other stories. The first bonus story had an all-too familiar theme: family and money – what could possibly go wrong? And the second … well, it was fun. :)...more

title: Inner Lives and Outer Selves
author: Maza, Cathleen*
my rating: 1 of 5 stars2 of 5 stars3 of 5 stars4 of 5 stars5 of 5 starsadd to shelves
review: I have read several collections of short fiction by this author and I keep coming back for more. In fact, it is the “something special” in her work thI have read several collections of short fiction by this author and I keep coming back for more. In fact, it is the “something special” in her work that makes me appreciate short fiction more than ever.Overall, what I truly admire about Ms. Maza’s work is that she skillfully plucks seemingly everyday stories from real life, crafts a story around them, then hits home so well. She nails such very important points in a way that feels effortless, but is not.I liked every story in this collection. I particularly liked “Mother’s Day” which tells the story of a woman, Abbey, who recalls different ages in her own past as she celebrates Mother’s Day with her own child, Chloe. For me, this story held so many truths that I imagine even readers with disparate lives will relate to the way Abbey works to resolve the pain of her own unhappy childhood.“Fate of the Fairy,” probably the shortest story in the book … was so incredibly poignant and I wondered how the author knew how I would feel about something many might see as insignificant. Again, it is Ms. Maza’s insight into the human psyche that comes shining through.And in the last story, “A Bistro in Paris,” where a woman resolves her unrequited past … without giving anything away, I can only say I was deeply touched by this. Again, I loved all of the stories.Cathleen Maza is truly one of the most relatable authors whose work I read. And yes, I will absolutely be back for more. Well done!...more
